turns.speaker: RED DRAGON
turns.text: THEY WILL FIND OUT ABOUT YOU.  THEY WILL LOCK YOU IN A PLACE WORSE THAN BROTHER BUDDY'S.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RED DRAGON
turns.text: THEY'LL MAKE YOU BE A PIECE OF SHIT AGAIN. THEY'LL MAKE YOU BE A HARELIP AGAIN. YOU BETTER GIVE ME WHAT I WANT!

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: RED DRAGON
turns.text: SHE'LL FUCK OTHER PEOPLE. PRETTY PEOPLE. SHE'LL PUT IN HER MOUTH THEIR...

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Shut up. Stop. Stop it.

turns.speaker: RED DRAGON
turns.text: YOU GIVE ME HER AND THE SHERMANS! YOU BETTER GIVE ME BOTH!

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: I want her! I want her alive...  I'm going to keep her! YOU HEAR ME!!!

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Are you cold? Would you like a blanket?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Was I in an accident?

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: No, Mr. Lounds. You'll be just fine.

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: My back hurts, my skin. Did I get burned? I hope to God I'm not burned.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Burned? Burned. No. You just rest there. I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Let me lie down.  Listen, I want to call my office. My God, I'm in a Stryker frame.  My back's broken. Tell me the truth.

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: What am I doing here?

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Atoning, Mr. Lounds.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you know who I am, Mr. Lounds?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: I don't want to know.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: According to you I'm a sexual failure. An animal, you said.  You know now, don't you?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you feel privileged?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: I'm very scared.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you pray to God, Mr. Lounds?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you believe God is in attendance here, Mr. Lounds?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: In a little while I'll help you understand.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Open your eyes, Mr. Lounds.

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: No. I don't want to see you.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Mr. Lounds, you're a reporter.  You're here to titillate your readers. If you don't open your eyes, I'll staple your eyelids to your forehead.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Look at the screen. That is William Blake's 'The Great Red Dragon and The Woman Clothed with the Sun.'  Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Mrs. Leeds harlequined with blood, her husband beside her. Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Mrs. Jacobi after her changing.  The Dragon rampant. Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Freddie Lounds. Your photograph. Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Oh, God.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you see?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Please, no.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: 'No' what?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Not me.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Are you a man?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Do you imply that I'm a queer?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: God, no.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Are you queer, Mr. Lounds?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Now you will read this into the tape recorder.

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: 'I have had a great privilege. I have seen with wonder the strength of the Red Dragon. All I wrote about him before was lies from Will Graham. He made me write them. Now I understand.  'Will Graham: you will learn from my own lips how much you have to dread. Because I was forced to lie, he will be more merciful to me than to you.  'I will be a testament to the truth, now.  About his work. About his becoming.'

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: You did very well.  I apologize for the crude images.  Next time I'll have film stock that doesn't need lights.

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: You'll let me go now?

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: You will tell the truth?

turns.speaker: LOUNDS
turns.text: Absolutely,

turns.speaker: DOLLARHYDE
turns.text: Good.  We'll seal your promise with...

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Come in.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Dr. Chilton.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: When we were cleaning out Dr. Lector's cell, he heard us coming and hid something in a book... We got him out of there and dug around...

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Do you have it?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Yeah. It's right here.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Put it down on my desk blotter and don't touch it again. Has anyone else handled it except you?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Dr. Lecktor will stay in his room. That is absolutely the only place where he is not put in full body restraints. One wall of his room is a double barrier. I will have a chair put just outside.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I might have to show him some material that could stimulate him.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: As long as it's on soft paper.  You may...  Find this curious.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: The consensus around here is that the only person who has demonstrated any practical understanding of Dr. Hannibal Lecktor is you, Mr. Graham. Can you tell me anything about him?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: When you saw Dr. Lecktor's murders, their 'style,' so to speak, were you able to reconstruct his fantasies? And did that help you identify him?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I want to see Lecktor now.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Uh... sure...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's Will Graham...

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Well, it's about goddamn time!  I have a note here, or two pieces of a note, that appears to be from the man who killed those people in Atlanta and....

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Where did you get it?!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Can you read it to me?

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: It's written on toilet tissue.  'My dear Dr. Lecktor, I wanted to tell you I'm delighted that you've taken an interest in me. I know that you alone can understand what I'm becoming.  'I know you alone understand the reality of the people who die to help me in these things, understand that they are only elements undergoing change to fuel the radiance of what I am becoming.  Just as the source of light is burning.  Mr. Graham, there's a hole torn and punched out, then it says...  'I have a complete collection of your press notices.  I think of them as unfair. As unfair as mine. The "Tooth Fairy." What could be more inappropriate.  Investigator Graham interests me.  Very purposeful looking. I hope we can correspond.  There's another piece missing here. I'll read the bottom part.  'After I hear back from you, I might send you something wet.  Signed: Avid Fan.  It has teethmarks pressed in it at the bottom.

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: In a holding cell.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: How long can you keep Lecktor out without him getting suspicious?

turns.speaker: DR. CHILTON
turns.text: Three, four hours.

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: Linda King's desk.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Hi, Linda. ..

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: Linda doesn't come in nights.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Maybe you can help me. This is Bob Greer of Blaine & Edwards Publishing Company. Dr. Bloom asked me to send a copy of 'The Psychiatrist and the Law' to someone. Linda never sent me the address and phone number.

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: She'll be in, in the morning...

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: I have to catch Federal Express within about five minutes. I'd be immensely appreciative if you'd pull it out of her Rolodex for me.

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: She doesn't have a Rolodex.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: I'll bet she has a call caddy right next to her phone.

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Well, zip that little pointer right on down to the letter G.

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: We're looking for Graham. The man the book is supposed to go to is a Mr. Will Graham.

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: Federal Bureau of Investigation, Tenth and Pennsylvania, Washington, D.C.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Now I'll bet it has his home address there, too

turns.speaker: GRADUATE STUDENT
turns.text: 3680 DeSoto Highway. Marathon, Florida.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: This is Will Graham. Can I help you?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: No. I can help you.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Atlanta and Birmingham.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Do you know something about that?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Why do you think I called?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I get a lot of calls. Most of them are from people who say they know things.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Talk to them a few minutes and you can tell they don't have the capacity to even understand what's going on. Do you?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: You tell me what you know about him. I'll tell you whether you're right or not.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Let's get straight who we've talking about.  Are you the man I'm interested in?

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: I don't think I'll tell you.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: He's right-handed.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Most people are.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: He's misunderstood.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Cut the general crap.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: He's very strong physically.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: That's true.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: He's white and six feet tall. You haven't told me anything yet.

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Describe exactly what you think he did to Mrs. Leeds and I'll tell you if you're right or not.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't want to do that,

turns.speaker: VOICE
turns.text: Goodbye.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: Our people swear he wore surgeons' gloves the whole time. They dusted everything.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: The report didn't mention nails and eyes.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: Why do you think he took his gloves off?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Mrs. Leeds was a good-looking woman. I'd want to touch her skin in an intimate situation, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: 'Intimate? !"

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. 'Intimate.' They had privacy.  Everybody else was dead.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: He may have a history of biting -- barroom fights or child abuse.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: He only bit women so far, right?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's all we know about.  Most of the time in sex assaults the bite mark has a livid spot in the center. A suck mark. These don't. So, for him, biting may be a fighting pattern as much as sexual behavior.  You could try emergency room personnel, treatment for bite wounds. I know that's pretty thin...  He bites a lot.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: What's average?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Sex murder: three. He likes to bite. Six bad ones in Mrs. Leeds.  Eight in Mrs. Jacobi...  ...that's all I have.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: The Commissioner was saying you were the one that caught Dr. Lecktor three years ago.  He killed nine people, didn't he?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Nine that we know of. Two didn't die.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: What happened to them?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: One's on the respirator at a hospital in Baltimore. The other is in a private mental hospital in Denver.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: What did the psychologists say was wrong with Lecktor?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Psychologists call him a sociopath. They don't know what else to call him.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: What would you call him?

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: To yourself...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I call him a monster.

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: I understand he cut you pretty good...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What about the dog?

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: It's at the vet's. The kids brought it in with a puncture wound in the abdomen. icepick or an awl.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Was the dog wearing a collar with the Leeds' name on it?

turns.speaker: SPRINGFIELD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Did the Jacobis in Birmingham have a dog?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: He stopped by to see me at the shop before he came out here.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What did he want?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: He asked how you are.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: And you said?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I said you are fine, he should leave you the hell alone.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm a forensic specialist, Molly. You've seen my diploma?  I got a diploma and everything.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: You mended a crack in the wallpaper with your diploma.  You are open and easy now... It took you a lot of work to get to that...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: We have it good, don't we?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: All the things that happened to you before make you know that...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What the hell can I do?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: What you've already decided. You're not really asking.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: If I were?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Stay here with me. Me. Me. Me.  And Kevin.  That's selfish, huh?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't care.  He'll never see me or know my name. If we find him, the police will have to take him down. Not me, I'm just looking at evidence.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Molly?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Huh?  Will? Is that you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's me. I'll call you tomorrow, sweetheart. Go back to sleep.  I love you...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Mmmmh... I love you, too, Will. Good night.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Hello, hotshot!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hey, baby! Where are you?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: At the store. You doin' some good?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: None you'd notice. I'm lonely...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Me, too. And very erotic...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Tell me about yourself.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Which part? That or the day-to-day.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Let's keep it the day-to-day stuff.  How's Kevin?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Kevin's fine. He had to recover the turtle eggs you two fenced in. The dogs dug them up. Tell me what you're doing.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Eating junk food.  They don't have a lock on anything, Molly. There's not enough information. Or I haven't done enough with it...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Will you be in Atlanta for a while? I'm not buggin' you about coming home, I just wondered.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't know. I'm goin' up to Baltimore this afternoon.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: To do what?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I have to see somebody.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I'm thinking about painting the kitchen. What color do you like, Will? Are you there?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yeah. Ah... yellow, let's paint it yellow.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Yellow's a bad color for me.  I'll look green at breakfast.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Blue, then.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Blue is cold.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hey, goddamn it, paint it shit-brown for all I care...  Look, I'm sorry. When I come home, we'll go to the paint store together and get some chips and...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Molly, dear Molly. Go to bed now, baby...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I love you...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: ...sorry, Molly. I'm sorry this happened to you.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: You didn't do it to me, Will; it's happened to us.  And if I survive the wallpaper we'll be okay...  He's after you now, isn't he?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: He didn't know you had been in a mental institution. Be asked me if I knew. I said yes. I wanted to talk to him. He said he wanted to bring it up to you. Face to face.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Good for him.  Thanks a lot, Freddie!  Kevin. We're going grocery shopping.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: You remember when we first met?  And were together alone in that room. And the exhilaration was too much to hold on to. And then something flickered across your face like a shadow and I asked you what was wrong?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I remember.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Do you remember what you said?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. I said this is too good to live...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Can I have one of your cigarettes?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You haven't smoked in two years.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I'd like one of your cigarettes, please.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Have you ever omitted telling me. things before?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Then why?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I wanted it over fast.  It felt dirty to not tell you.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Can you quit?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: And... where are things?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Where we're at is nowhere. We have nothing. We're running out of time.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: What will you do?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I have to go back to Birmingham.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Is Crawford going with you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No. I have to be in there...  alone. Maybe there's something for me if I know how he feels and thinks.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: William: you are going to make yourself sick or get yourself killed.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You should go to Montana. Stay with Kevin's grandparents. They haven't seen him for a while.  I'll come and get you afterwards...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Will...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I was out in the garden. Mama came out and told me when she saw it on TV. Why didn't you call me?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Mama was probably asleep.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Will? Are you okay?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Not too bad. I'll be here a few days longer.  I want to see you.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I want to see you, too.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Today's Wednesday. By Friday I ought to...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Mama has all Kevin's uncles and aunts coming down from Cheyenne next week and...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Come home with me.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Will, they never get to see Kevin and a few more days...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What's this Mama shit?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: It's what Kevin called her when he was little...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What's the problem, Molly?

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: I came up here after Kevin's father died.  They were very supportive and helped me adjust. I got myself together. I've gotten myself together now, too.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Small difference: I'm not dead, yet.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Will?  You could come up here.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: They don't want me up there. Every time they look at me I remind them... If they thought about it, they'd want you. Bur all they really want's the boy. And they'll take you.  But they don't want to see me...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: That's not true.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Okay. They're full of shit and they make me sick...

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Maybe we should give it some time...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yeah. That's great. A little time.  I tell you what, buckaroo...  See you around.

turns.speaker: MOLLY
turns.text: Let's forget who said what to whom...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You got a deal...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's Will Graham. Is Molly there, Mr. Swenson?

turns.speaker: GRAMPA
turns.text: Well, how you doin', Mr. Graham?! You sure are in the center of a storm. Burning up lots of taxpayer's dollars, too, I bet.  On the news they said he was a white man. He isn't really, is he?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Sure he is. Blond.  Probably Scandinavian, too...

turns.speaker: GRAMPA
turns.text: You going back down to Florida after?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. Is Molly there?

turns.speaker: GRAMPA
turns.text: My grandboy's been eatin' a ton of breakfast every day. Been out riding. Must be the good air. You oughta see that little booger eat.  I'll bet he's gained ten pounds.  Molly's out in the motor home...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I know... 'Out in the good air...'

turns.speaker: GRAMPA
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Tell her I called.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Thanks for the lift.

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: I'll come inside with you, if you like, but Mr. Crawford said you'd probably want to be alone.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: There's a VTR setup waiting in your hotel room, that you asked for. They transferred the home movies of both families onto half-inch VHS.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: Meet point's up ahead!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Go on to the house.

turns.speaker: OFFICER
turns.text: Lt. Fisk said...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Go on to the house...

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Are you George Sherman?

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: Yes. Who are you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: My name's Will Graham. I...

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: Oh, Jesus... Come in.  Honey...!

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: We're fine. Fine. We're all well. We're okay!  That man, Crawford, called and... told me...  ...how 'bout a drink? Coffee or something?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No, I'm okay. I just wanted to...  ...stop by and...

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: I can't thank you enough, I...

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Will it keep them out?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yeah...

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: How many turtle eggs you think are in here?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: In this hatchery? Forty to fifty.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Crabs would get most of the newborns before they made it to the sea, huh?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yeah, but not now... These will all make it... guaranteed.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's a precaution...  Why don't you run down to the bay. They got a swimming float.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: I'll hang around in here. I'll just be in the kitchen, Mom...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What is he? Afraid to leave you alone with me now?'  He read the Tattler piece, didn't he?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Is there anything I need to know to see about Mom?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No. You're very well-protected.  No one can find our where you are.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Barry's mom had this newspaper. It said you killed the guy in Minnesota and were in a mental hospital. Is it true?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: I figured I'd ask you...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I was in the psychiatric wing. It bothers you, finding out I was in there... doesn't it?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: I told my dad before he died, I'd take care of Mom. And I'll do it.  This guy wants to kill you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: We don't know that.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Are you gonna kill him?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No. It's just my job to find him.  I was in the hospital after Garrett Jacob Hobbs.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: How did it happen?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Hobbs was insane. He was attacking college girls and he killed them.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: With a knife.  I found a curly piece of metal in the clothes of one of the girls. The kind of shred a pipe threader makes. I was taking a look at steam fitters, plumbers. It took a long time. In one place there was a resignation letter from a man named Hobbs. I saw it and it was..., peculiar.  I was going up these stairs to Hobbs' apartment. I was halfway up when he shoved his wife down at me. She was dying.  I sent the officer with me to call a SWAT team. But I could hear kids in there and screaming. I couldn't wait.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: You went in the apartment?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. Hobbs had one of his daughters from behind. He was cutting her. I shot him.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Did the girl die?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: She got all right?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: ...after a while.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: And Hobbs died?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: ...yes.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: What kind of coffee do you like?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: You like that Colombian stuff, don't you?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: That's the same atrocious aftershave you wore in court three years ago.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I keep getting it for Christmas.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Did you get my card?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I got it. Thank you.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: And how is Officer Stuart? The one who was the first to see my basement.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Stuart is fine.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Emotional problems, I hear. He was a very promising young officer. Do you ever have any problems, Will?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Of course, you don't.  I'm glad you came. My callers are all professional. Clinical psychiatrists from cornfield colleges somewhere. Second-raters, the lot.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Dr. Bloom showed me your article on surgical addiction in the journal of Clinical Psychiatry.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Very interesting, even to a layman.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: A layman..., layman. Interesting term. So many experts on government grants. And you say you're a 'layman?' But it was you who caught me, wasn't it, Will? Do you know how you did it'

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You've read the transcript. It's all there.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: No it's not. Do you know how you did it Will?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's in the transcript. What does it matter now?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: It doesn't matter to me, Will.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I want you to help me, Dr. Lecktor.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Yes, I thought so.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: It's about Atlanta and Birmingham.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You read about it, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: In the papers. I don't tear out the articles.  I wouldn't want them to think I was dwelling on anything morbid. You want to know how he's choosing them, don't you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I thought you would have some ideas.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Why should I tell you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: There are things you don't have. Research materials... I could speak to the Chief of Staff...?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Chilton? Gruesome, isn't he? He fumbles at your head like a freshman pulling at a panty girdle.  He actually tries to give me a Thematic and Apperception test. Hah. Sat there waiting for MF-13 to come up. It's a card with a woman in bed and a man in the foreground.  I was supposed to avoid a sexual interpretation. I laughed in his face.  Never mind, it's boring.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You'll get to see the file on this case. And there's another reason.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Pray tell.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I thought you might be curious to find our if you're smarter than the person I'm looking for.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Then by implication, you think that you are smarter than me, since you caught me.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No. I knew that I'm not smarter than you are.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Then how did you catch me, Will?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You had disadvantages.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: What disadvantage?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: You're insane.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: You're very tan, Will.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Don't think you can persuade me with appeals to my intellectual vanity.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't think I'll persuade you. You'll do it or you won't. Dr. Bloom is working an it anyway, and he's the best...

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Do you have the file with you

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Pictures?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Let me have them, and I might consider it.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Do you dream much, Will?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Good-bye, Dr. Lecktor.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: You haven't threatened to take away my books yet.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: What were the yards like?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Big backyards, fences, some hedges, why?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Because, my dear Will, if this Pilgrim imagines he has a relationship with the full moon, he might go outside and look at it.  Have you seen blood in moonlight, Will? It appears quite black. If one were nude, it would be better to have outdoor privacy for this sort of thing.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: That's interesting.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: It's not 'interesting'. You thought of it before.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes. I'd considered it.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: You came here to look at me, Will. To get the old scent again, didn't you?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I want your opinion.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: I don't have one right now.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: When you do have one I'd like to hear it.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: May I keep the file?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I haven't decided yet.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: I'll study it, Will. When you get more files, I'd like to see them, too. You can call me. When I have to call my lawyer, they bring me a telephone. Would you like to give me your home number?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: Do you know how you caught me, Will?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Goodbye, Dr. Lecktor. You can leave messages for me at the number on the file.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: I wanted to congratulate you for the job you did on Mr. Lounds. I admired it enormously. What a cunning boy you are, Will.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: You know Lounds's enlightened me on one thing: your confinement in the mental hospital. My attorney should have brought that our in court.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm worn out with you crazy sons-of- bitches. If you've got something to say, Lecktor, say it.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: I want to help you, Will. You'd be more comfortable if you relaxed with yourself. We don't invent our natures, They're issued to us.  Along with our lungs and pancreas and everything else. Why fight it?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Fight what?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: When you were so depressed after you shot Mr. Garrett Jacob Hobbs to death, it wasn't the act that got you down. Didn't you really feel so bad because killing him felt so good?  And why shouldn't it feel good?! It must feel good to God. God does it all the time!

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: I don't believe in God.

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: You should, Will. God's terrific!  He dropped a church roof on thirty- four of His worshippers in Texas last Wednesday night. Just as they were groveling to Him and singing a hymn.  Don't you think that felt good?  He wouldn't begrudge you two measly murders.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Why does it feel good?

turns.speaker: LECKTOR
turns.text: It feels good because: if you do as God does, enough times, you become as God is: powerful...

turns.speaker: SPURGEN
turns.text: ...if he's smart he'll approach from the front, pass, and take you from the back. How well do you hear?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Pretty well.

turns.speaker: SPURGEN
turns.text: I'm gonna spray your suit jackets. It'll be invisible in this light, but you'll stand out like a zebra for us.  They told me you checked out a .44 Charter Arms Bulldog.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SPURGEN
turns.text: Good. You'll load these, Ever fire them?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Glaser Safety Slugs?

turns.speaker: SPURGEN
turns.text: ...commercially prohibited.  Number Twelve shot in liquid Teflon in a copper casing. On impact it all opens up in the target. Expect the recoil. They're hot loads.  Body armor?

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Kevlar Second Chance.

turns.speaker: SPURGEN
turns.text: I hope you have a second chance...

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Because he's gone for the head shot seven out of eight times'

turns.speaker: SPURGEN
turns.text: You got it.

turns.speaker: GRAHAM
turns.text: Let's walk the route.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey, I really enjoyed your set.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Tank you veddy much.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: So I understand you're from Lithuania?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No.  Caspiar.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Caspiar?  I haven't heard of that.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: It's a veddy small island in de Caspian Sea.  It sunk. GEORGE Oh.  Hm.  I'm uh, sorry.  Well, look, I'm probably out of my mind -- but I think you're very interesting.  If you ever need representation... we should talk.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: People love... comedians.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm not a comedian.  I have no talent.  I'm a song-and-dance man.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You show a lot of promise... but... my concern is I don't know where to book you.  You're not a stand-up... your act doesn't exactly translate to films... help me... where do you see yourself?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I've always wanted to play Carnegie Hall.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy, c'mon IN!  Thanks for flyin' out here!!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The stewardess let me keep my headphones.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's... terrific!  But I got something better.  This is BIG...  You are getting a once-in-a- lifetime, unbelievably lucrative opportunity to star on... a PRIMETIME NETWORK SITCOM!!!!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sitcom...?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And this is a CLASS ACT!  It's the guys who did the Mary Tyler Moore and Bob Newhart shows!  It takes place in a taxi stand!  And you're gonna be the Fonzie!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm -- Fonzie? GEORGE NO!  The Fonzie!  The crazy breakout character!  The guy that all the kids impersonate and put on their lunchboxes!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: George, I hate sitcoms.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: HANG ON, you ain't heard the best part!  ABC has seen your foreign man character, and they want to turn him into --  "Latka," a lovable, goofy mechanic!!!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: "No"?  "No" to which part??

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No to the whole thing.  None of it sounds good.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy... this is every comedian's dream.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I told you, I'm not a comedian.  And sitcoms are the lowest form of entertainment: Stupid jokes and canned laughter.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: B-but, this is classy... they did Bob Newha--

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm not interested.  I want to create my own material.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You have to do it.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I refuse.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: LISTEN, you arrogant putz!  I've been in this business for twenty years!  I know!  If you walk away from this opportunity, you will never, NEVER see another one like it again!!!!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Okay.  Fine, I'll do it.  But I have a few terms.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Of course!  That's what negotiations are for.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Are you makin' fun of me --?  This is RIDICULOUS!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Those are my terms.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: They're IMPOSSIBLE!!  Jesus!  I mean -- "two guaranteed guest shots for Tony Clifton"??!  Who is this TONY CLIFTON?!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: He's a Vegas entertainer.  I used to do impressions of him.  We sorta... got in a fight over that.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hi George!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Eh, hi, Andy.  Look, this Tony Clifton... is he performing anywhere?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Of course.  But only on Monday nights.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's alright.  Where...?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, I'm sorry.  They're assholes! But we work in a creative business. You can't predict what people are gonna like --

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The ONLY reason I did Taxi was so I could have my own Special!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Tell you what.  I'll book you on some concerts, and meanwhile, we'll show the Special around... see if somebody wants to buy it --

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Yeah, we can have a garage sale. "Hey look, I got a floor lamp and a network TV Special for only fifty cents!"

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You signed for five years --  So four years, seven months.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Okay... I'll go back.  But just let them know, first they ain't gettin' Latka.  They're gettin' Tony!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm sorry, George...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're DAMN RIGHT you're sorry!  And you -- you're the road manager! You should be watchin' out for him!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: When you play the Midwest and South, you DON'T MINDFUCK THESE PEOPLE! It's not postmodern -- it's rude.  If you wanna perform in Texas, you give 'em Mighty Mouse!  You give 'em Elvis!!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: But George, I like to push the boundaries...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And that's great.  But do it in LA and New York!  There you experiment! Show up with a sleeping bag and take a nap on stage!  I don't care!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: How long would they let me sleep?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know!  Andy... you need to look inside: Who are you trying to entertain?  The audience... or yourself?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hi, George!  Good to hear from you!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hi, Andy.  How's the weather up there?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Oh, you know the Bay Area!  Always foggy!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm here with Ed over at Taxi. There's been some trouble with Tony.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Oh no!  Did he get hurt?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Oh dear!  George, this is gonna kill Tony. He's waited his whole life for this break.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: There'll be other shots.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're so proud.  You're like some retarded kid comin' home from school: "Look, Dad, I got an F!"

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: But wasn't it funny?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: "Funny"?  I dunno.  But "intriguing"... "mindboggling"... perhaps "headache-inducing"... sure.  Like, that moment, when you both came onstage...

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: George... I'm at a stage where the audience expects me to constantly shock them.  But short of faking my death, or setting the theater on fire, I don't know what else to do.  'Cause I've always got to be one step ahead of them.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But I feel you're extending this philosophy to real life.  It's obsessive.  Nothing's ever on the level anymore.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: That means it was a success.  I woke up the audience -- like punk rock!  Here, take this.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, I'm not gonna take it.  If I take it I'll break my back.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: They're having a laugh...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: WRONG!  You haven't given them any clues that it's a parody!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: That's because they've only seen it once.  But I'll do it again, and again, and AGAIN...  They'll catch on!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy, do you realize you don't do comedy anymore?  Where's that sweet guy who used to do  "Here I come to save the day!"?  Please, enough with the wrestling! You've lost touch with reality!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What, you don't think I can beat him?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: He is the Southern Heavyweight Champion.  He'll kill you.  First, you piss-off women.  Then you piss-off the South.  Then you get killed!  And I did the bookings.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: We were just trying to push the envelope --

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're BLIND!  There is no envelope anymore!!  It hurts me to say this... but there's only one solution --  I don't want you two to ever work together again.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Maybe I can turn it into a bit.  I can go back on the show, and say it was rigged.  Demand a recount...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy!  You don't get it!  They don't want you back.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Hey!  Our first phone call!  Hello?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy... it's me.  I've got some crummy news.  Taxi's been canceled.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The world thinks Andy Kaufman sucks. So I was just giving 'em what they want...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Andy, they don't think you suck. They've just... lost a reason to love you.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No, it's true.  I have lung cancer.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's ridiculous.  You don't even smoke.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I -- I got some freaky rare kind. It's called large-celled carcinoma.
